headline: Can this ‘woolly mouse’ help bring back extinct mammoths?
context: Scientists are working to unlock the secrets to bringing back extinct animals. One potentially important new advance is the creation of genetically altered mice with long, golden locks of tufted fur. They were, in fact, inspired by the coats of woolly mammoths.
The new rodents are being called Colossal woolly mice. And yes, they’re super cute.

annotations.paragraph: As transgenic mice, their genes have been tweaked by engineering. That in itself is not all that special. What’s notable here is that eight spots have been edited across seven genes.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the genetic engineering process used on the mice.

annotations.paragraph: The team did three experiments. Each used a different mix of edits. In all, they created 32 woolly mice. Each varied slightly in appearance.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives information about the experiments conducted and the results obtained.

annotations.paragraph: All, however, carried the hoped-for traits, notes Beth Shapiro. An evolutionary biologist, she works at the University of California, Santa Cruz. She’s also chief science officer at Colossal Biosciences in Dallas, Texas. There, she was part of a team working on the new mice.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about the traits of the mice and introduces a key scientist involved in the project.

annotations.paragraph: Their gene editing worked well, Shapiro says. They got seemingly healthy animals with some mammoth-like traits. There also were no surprises, she says — “other than that they were so absurdly adorable.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers direct commentary from a scientist about the success of the gene editing.

annotations.paragraph: Her team described its achievement in a paper that posted March 4 at bioRxiv.org.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a reference to the scientific publication of the research.

annotations.paragraph: So what can we expect when it comes to bringing back extinct species? Colossal Biosciences’ founder, Ben Lamm, has said he wants woolly mammoth calves on the ground by 2028.
annotations.reason: Provides a specific goal and timeline related to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Can they achieve that?
annotations.reason: Poses a question without providing new information.

annotations.paragraph: They’ll start by tweaking Asian elephant genes to be more mammoth-like. Later, they’ll need to put mammoth-like embryos into another animal — likely an elephant — to serve as each calf’s mom.
annotations.reason: Explains the process of how they plan to bring back mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: “We will have elephant cells that are edited and ready to go in early ’27,” Shapiro says. That’s “what we would need to have [calves] on the ground in 2028.” However, she adds, “There’s a lot of hard biology that still hasn’t been solved.” And before those calves are actually born, “that needs to be solved.”
annotations.reason: Provides a timeline and acknowledges challenges in the process.

annotations.paragraph: To create the woolly mouse, scientists analyzed all the genetic instructions — or genomes — in 121 tissue samples from mammoths and elephants. The goal here was to find the genes that might have given woolly mammoths some of their key traits. Those include long, thick, golden hair. They also include genes for absorbing and using fat — important features for animals that lived in the bitter cold.
annotations.reason: Describes the scientific process and goals related to the woolly mouse and mammoth traits.

annotations.paragraph: “We can do a lot with the mammoth genomes we have,” says Shapiro. “We can line them up on a computer and compare them to elephant genomes.”
annotations.reason: This quote provides insight into the genetic comparison process between mammoths and elephants.

annotations.paragraph: In this way, her team compared “where all the [mammoths’ genes] are the same as each other but different from their elephant cousins.”
annotations.reason: This explains the method used to identify genetic differences crucial for mammoth characteristics.

annotations.paragraph: Those differences pointed to what should make a mammoth a mammoth.
annotations.reason: This highlights the significance of genetic differences in defining mammoth traits.

annotations.paragraph: The researchers then searched for similar traits in mice. Those could be in naturally occurring genes — or in ones that might be added through genetic engineering.
annotations.reason: This describes the approach to finding mammoth-like traits in mice, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Mice are much easier to work with than elephants. The tiny rodents require little space. They also breed quickly. And being extensively studied, their genes are already well understood.
annotations.reason: This provides context on why mice are used in genetic research, relevant to the study's methodology.

annotations.paragraph: For instance, scientists have known since 1994 that mice will grow much longer hair than usual if you turn off a gene known as FGF5. Similarly, a gene known as Mc1r makes mice blond. And the gene Frzd6 makes that hair whorly and frizzled.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific scientific details about the genetic modifications used to create the woolly mice.

annotations.paragraph: The final step in creating the new woolly mice: editing embryos’ genes to help them become living, breathing, gloriously furred mice.
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes the crucial step in the process of creating the woolly mice, contributing to the narrative of the scientific advancement.

annotations.paragraph: Submit your question here, and we might answer it an upcoming issue of Science News Explores
annotations.reason: This is a call to action unrelated to the article's main topic.

annotations.paragraph: This gene-tweaking worked with high efficiency. In other words, the scientists not only made woolly mice, but could do so reliably and repeatedly. And that’s actually a big deal, says Shapiro.
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights the success and significance of the genetic modification process.

annotations.paragraph: “Of course, mice are not elephants,” she acknowledges. Indeed, it’s something critics have often “pointed out to us,” she adds.
annotations.reason: This quote addresses a potential criticism and provides context to the limitations of the research.

annotations.paragraph: And that’s why, she says, these woolly mice are just one part of her team’s de-extinction goal. Colossal Biosciences, started in 2021, has also been experimenting directly with Asian elephant cells. The reason: That species is related most closely to extinct woolly mammoths.
annotations.reason: Provides information on the broader de-extinction goals and related research with Asian elephant cells.

annotations.paragraph: Another arm of the company’s research focuses on techniques to improve artificial reproduction. These are skills that will be needed to implant a genetically modified elephant embryo into a living elephant — one that would ultimately give birth to a “mammoth” calf.
annotations.reason: Details the techniques being developed for artificial reproduction, crucial for the de-extinction process.

annotations.paragraph: In related work, this team also is working on efforts to bring back the extinct dodo and the thylacine. That last animal, also known as the Tasmanian wolf, was actually a wolflike marsupial.
annotations.reason: Mentions other de-extinction projects, providing context on the scope of the company's efforts.

annotations.paragraph: Jacquelyn Gill is an ice-age ecologist. She works at the University of Maine in Orono. Gill doesn’t hide her excitement about the idea of one day seeing a real live woolly mammoth.
annotations.reason: Introduces a relevant expert and her perspective on the de-extinction project.

annotations.paragraph: “I understand why someone would be compelled to see a mammoth,” she says. In much the same way, she explains, “I’ve never seen [the ice age] in person, right? It only exists in my mind’s eye, because I study a past that is gone.”
annotations.reason: Provides a quote from an expert expressing the emotional and intellectual appeal of de-extinction.

annotations.paragraph: She does not reject the idea of trying to bring back extinct species. In fact, Gill says, “the science of de-extinction is exciting and has broad applications.”
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a relevant quote about the potential of de-extinction science.

annotations.paragraph: She is skeptical, however, that what Colossal Biosciences is working on will qualify as bringing a woolly mammoth back from the dead.
annotations.reason: The paragraph directly addresses skepticism about the project's goals.

annotations.paragraph: For starters, many well-preserved mammoth remains have been discovered in permafrost. In some cases, they were complete carcasses with fur, muscles and skin. However, they also had been buried in ice for thousands of years. And that likely destroyed every cell in those remains.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides context on the challenges of using mammoth remains for de-extinction.

annotations.paragraph: “A mammoth is not an elephant in a fur coat.”
annotations.reason: The quote highlights a key distinction relevant to the de-extinction discussion.

annotations.paragraph: Without intact cells, researchers won’t be able to clone a mammoth as easily as some in the past had cloned sheep. “That’s a whole pathway to cloning that is cut off from us,” Gill says.
annotations.reason: The paragraph explains a significant limitation in cloning mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: Gene editing may allow researchers to alter an Asian elephant in ways that make it resemble a woolly mammoth. But any effort to do so will likely miss untold genetic traits that made woolly mammoths unique as a species.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the potential and limitations of gene editing in the context of reviving mammoth-like traits, directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Keep in mind, emphasizes Tori Herridge, “A mammoth is not an elephant in a fur coat.” An evolutionary biologist, she works at the University of Sheffield in England.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a relevant expert quote that highlights the complexity of reviving mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: Herridge does find the idea of identifying candidate genes for mammoth fur and for cold adaptation “really exciting and interesting.” Still, she cautions, we don’t know “what makes a mammoth a mammoth.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers expert commentary on the challenges of identifying specific mammoth traits, relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: “We all know that genes are complicated,” she says. “One gene can affect many things.” And many genes can act together. What’s more, she points out, researchers don’t yet know if the genes for hair length, texture or color in the woolly mice will produce the same effects in Asian elephants.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information on the complexity of gene interactions and their implications for the project.

annotations.paragraph: Some work can be done to test this in the lab, Shapiro says. For instance, her team is already growing elephant cells in a lab dish. They can then test how those cells respond to things like possible changes in how or where in tissues a gene is active.
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes ongoing research efforts, directly contributing to the narrative of reviving mammoth traits.

annotations.paragraph: This allows Colossal to learn more about which genes to target without having to grow or experiment each time on a whole elephant.
annotations.reason: It explains the practical advantage of using woolly mice in genetic research related to mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: Its team has already created elephant stem cells. These are the pluripotent type. That means they could potentially be used to create any type of cell (from skin or heart to bone or brain). That’s a key step toward assisting reproduction of an animal — with the goal of one day moving a gene-edited elephant embryo into an elephant to serve as its surrogate mother.
annotations.reason: It provides essential information on the progress and goals of the genetic research related to de-extinction.

annotations.paragraph: Complicating this last step is the fact that pregnancy in an Asian elephant can last almost two years. So taking each gene-edited elephant embryo to birth in such a surrogate would take far, far longer than bringing forth a woolly mouse. After all, the mouse’s pregnancy lasts just 18 to 21 days.
annotations.reason: It offers relevant context on the challenges of using elephants as surrogates compared to mice.

annotations.paragraph: Another possible complication: The International Union for Conservation of Nature classifies Asian elephants as endangered with extinction. So this species’ rarity could limit anyone’s permission to use it for a surrogate mom.
annotations.reason: It provides relevant information on the ethical and logistical challenges of using endangered elephants in the research.

annotations.paragraph: For her part, Shapiro remains optimistic that something like de-extinction is possible.
annotations.reason: It is a vague generalization without specific information or context.

annotations.paragraph: In fact, one of her company’s other projects might succeed first: bringing back the dodo. After all, she notes, it lays an egg. That means it doesn’t need a surrogate mother.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is about a different project (the dodo) and not directly related to the woolly mouse or mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: Even assuming that all of this will be possible one day — and in numbers sufficient to create a healthy-size herd of woolly mammoths — other questions remain.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces potential challenges and questions about the main topic of bringing back mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: For one, scientists have shown that modern-day elephants are complex animals with established social and cultural knowledge. It’s something they pass down from one generation to the next. So, Gill asks, who’s to teach the first generation about “how to be a woolly mammoth?”
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses a specific challenge related to the main topic of reviving mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: The habitat that mammoths enjoyed has changed quite a bit, too, since their herds roamed the Pleistocene Epoch (which ended 11,700 years ago).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant context about the changes in habitat since the time of the mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: Back then, the tundra would have been full of life, Gill says. You might think of it as being much like Africa’s Serengeti is today.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers additional context about the mammoths' historical habitat, relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: This type of ecosystem — known as the mammoth steppe — was once the most widespread on Earth. Today’s northerly ecosystems, in contrast, host far fewer species. And the populations of species that can survive there also tend to be smaller.
annotations.reason: Provides context about the mammoth steppe ecosystem relevant to the potential impact of bringing back mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: But mammoths were keystone species, meaning ones that changed their environment. Mammoths may have made the mammoth steppe. And maybe it disappeared largely because the mammoths did.
annotations.reason: Explains the role of mammoths as keystone species, relevant to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: So if mammoths made an ecosystem once, could they maybe do so again?
annotations.reason: Poses a question directly related to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: In theory, new mammoths could alter their ecosystem in ways that would nurture their reborn species, Gill says. And that idea is key to one of Colossal Bioscience’s goals: Bringing back herds of mammoths to again stamp down permafrost and help keep carbon stored in the ground. This might be one “old” way to protect against further climate change.
annotations.reason: Discusses the potential environmental impact of bringing back mammoths, directly related to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: How likely is that? Right now, Gill admits, “we don’t actually know.”
annotations.reason: Acknowledges uncertainty in the feasibility of the project, relevant to the article's exploration of the topic.

annotations.paragraph: adaptation: (in biology) The development of new programs, processes, policies and structures to make communities and their inhabitants better able to head off — or at least withstand — the dangerous impacts of a warming climate. Those impacts may include drought, flooding, wildfires, extreme heat and extreme storms.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic of bringing back extinct animals.

annotations.paragraph: biology: The study of living things. The scientists who study them are known as biologists.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a general definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: breed: (noun) Animals within the same species that are so genetically similar that they produce reliable and characteristic traits. German shepherds and dachshunds, for instance, are examples of dog breeds. (verb) To produce offspring through reproduction.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: calf: (plural: calves) The name of young animals in a range of mammalian species, from cattle to walruses.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: carcass: The body of a dead animal.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: cell: (in biology) The smallest structural and functional unit of an organism. Typically too small to see with the unaided eye, it consists of a watery fluid surrounded by a membrane or wall. Depending on their size, animals are made of anywhere from thousands to trillions of cells.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides general biological information unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: climate change: Long-term, significant change in the climate of Earth. It can happen naturally or in response to human activities, including the burning of fossil fuels and clearing of forests.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides general information about climate change unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: clone: An exact copy (or what seems to be an exact copy) of some physical object. (in biology) An organism that has exactly the same genes as another, like identical twins. Often a clone, particularly among plants, has been created using the cell of an existing organism. Clone also is the term for making offspring that are genetically identical to some “parent” organism. (v.) To make an exact copy of some physical object.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides general information about cloning unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: conservation: The act of preserving or protecting something. The focus of this work can range from art objects to endangered species and other aspects of the natural environment.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides general information about conservation unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: ecologist: A scientist who works in a branch of biology that deals with the relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides general information about ecologists unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: ecosystem: A group of interacting living organisms — including microorganisms, plants and animals — and their physical environment within a particular climate. Examples include tropical reefs, rainforests, alpine meadows and polar tundra. The term can also be applied to elements that make up some an artificial environment, such as a company, classroom or the internet.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic of genetically altered mice or extinct mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: egg: A reproductive cell that contains half of the genetic information necessary to form a complete organism. In humans and in many other animals, ovaries produce eggs. When an egg fuses with a sperm, they combine to produce a new cell, called a zygote. This is the first step in the development of a new organism."
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic of genetically altered mice or extinct mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: embryo: The early stages of a developing organism, or animal with a backbone, consisting only one or a few cells. As an adjective, the term would be embryonic — and could be used to refer to the early stages or life of a system or technology.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic of genetically altered mice or extinct mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: endangered: An adjective used to describe species at risk of going extinct.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic of genetically altered mice or extinct mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: engineering: The field of research that uses math and science to solve practical problems. Someone who works in this field is known as an engineer.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic of genetically altered mice or extinct mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: environment: The sum of all of the things that exist around some organism or the process and the condition those things create. Environment may refer to the weather and ecosystem in which some animal lives, or, perhaps, the temperature and humidity (or even the placement of things in the vicinity of an item of interest).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition of 'environment' and does not contribute directly to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: evolutionary biologist: Someone who studies the adaptive processes that have led to the diversity of life on Earth. These scientists can study many different subjects, including the microbiology and genetics of living organisms, how species change to adapt, and the fossil record (to assess how various ancient species are related to each other and to modern-day relatives).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition of 'evolutionary biologist' and does not contribute directly to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: extinction: (adj. extinct) The permanent loss of a species, family or larger group of organisms.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition of 'extinction' and does not contribute directly to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: gene: (adj. genetic) A segment of DNA that codes, or holds instructions, for a cell’s production of a protein. Offspring inherit genes from their parents. Genes influence how an organism looks and behaves.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition of 'gene' and does not contribute directly to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: gene editing: The deliberate introduction of changes to genes by researchers.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition of 'gene editing' and does not contribute directly to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: generation: A group of individuals (in any species) born at about the same time or that are regarded as a single group. Your parents belong to one generation of your family, for example, and your grandparents to another. Similarly, you and everyone within a few years of your age across the planet are referred to as belonging to a particular generation of humans.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: genetic engineering: The direct manipulation of an organism’s genome. In this process, genes can be removed, disabled so that they no longer function, or added after being taken from other organisms. Genetic engineering can be used to create organisms that produce medicines, or crops that grow better under challenging conditions such as dry weather, hot temperatures or salty soils.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant context about genetic engineering, which is related to the creation of genetically altered mice.

annotations.paragraph: genome: The complete set of genes or genetic material in a cell or an organism. The study of this genetic inheritance housed within cells is known as genomics.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: gestation: The time an animal takes to develop inside its mother’s body.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: habitat: The area or natural environment in which an animal or plant normally lives, such as a desert, coral reef or freshwater lake. A habitat can be home to thousands of different species.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: host: (in biology and medicine) The organism (or environment) in which some other thing resides. Humans may be a temporary host for food-poisoning germs or other infective agents. (v.) The act of providing a home or environment for something. A website, for instance, could host photos, news or other types of information.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: implant: A device manufactured to replace a missing biological structure, to support a damaged biological structure, or to enhance an existing biological structure. Examples include artificial hips, knees and teeth; pacemakers; and the insulin pumps used to treat diabetes. Or some device installed surgically into an animal’s body to collect information on the individual (such as its temperature, blood pressure or activity cycle). (v. to insert something into something else)
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: keystone species: A species that plays a particularly large role on maintaining the ecosystem it inhabits. Such species tend to keep their communities diverse by helping to prevent an overabundance of certain other species or by helping ensure the availability of needed resources to other species in its ecosystem.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: marsupial: A type of mammal that carries its young for a period after birth in external pouches. There the developing babies have access to their mother’s nipples — and milk. Most of these species evolved in Australian and have especially long hind-legs. Examples of marsupials include kangaroos, opossums and koalas.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: muscle: A type of tissue used to produce movement by contracting its cells, known as muscle fibers. Muscle is rich in protein, which is why predatory species seek prey containing lots of this tissue.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: permafrost: Soil that remains frozen for at least two consecutive years. Such conditions typically occur in polar climates, where average annual temperatures remain close to or below freezing.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides background information unrelated to the main topic of genetically altered mice or mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: Pleistocene: The earlier epoch of the Quaternary Period. It ranged from 2.6 million to 11,700 years ago. The term can also refer to rocks that from this period. During this time, periods of Ice Ages and interglacial warming occurred. The mammoth was one of the largest land animals from this time.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context about the Pleistocene epoch and mammoths, which is relevant to the topic of bringing back extinct mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: pluripotent: A term that means having many possibilities. In medicine, pluripotent is an adjective used to describe a type of stem cell that can mature into any other type of cell in the body.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic of genetically altered mice or mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: population: (in biology) A group of individuals (belonging to the same species) that lives in a given area.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition unrelated to the main topic of genetically altered mice or mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: rodent: A mammal of the order Rodentia, a group that includes mice, rats, squirrels, guinea pigs, hamsters and porcupines.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition unrelated to the main topic of genetically altered mice or mammoths.

annotations.paragraph: skeptical: Not easily convinced; having doubts or reservations.
annotations.reason: This is a definition and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: social: (adj.) Relating to gatherings of people; a term for animals (or people) that prefer to exist in groups. (noun) A gathering of people, for instance those who belong to a club or other organization, for the purpose of enjoying each other’s company.
annotations.reason: This is a definition and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: species: A group of similar organisms capable of producing offspring that can survive and reproduce.
annotations.reason: This is a definition and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: stem cell: A “blank slate” cell that can give rise to other types of cells in the body. Stem cells play an important role in tissue regeneration and repair.
annotations.reason: This is a definition and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: steppe: The term for a vast, wild grassland that is typically devoid of trees (except near rivers), especially in Southeastern Europe or Asia.
annotations.reason: This is a definition and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: surrogate: A substitute; something that stands in or takes the place of another. In reproduction, it's one animal that is used to bring to birth some foreign embryo (one produced by reproductive cells belonging to another "mother").
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: theory: (in science) A description of some aspect of the natural world based on extensive observations, tests and reason. A theory can also be a way of organizing a broad body of knowledge that applies in a broad range of circumstances to explain what will happen. Unlike the common definition of theory, a theory in science is not just a hunch. Ideas or conclusions that are based on a theory — and not yet on firm data or observations — are referred to as theoretical. Scientists who use mathematics and/or existing data to project what might happen in new situations are known as theorists.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: thylacine: Also known as the Tasmanian tiger, it was once the world’s largest marsupial. But overhunting wiped this predator species out. The last wild member of this species was shot in 1930. The last captive thylacine died six years later.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information about a different extinct species, not directly related to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: tissue: Made of cells, it is any of the distinct types of materials that make up animals, plants or fungi. Cells within a tissue work as a unit to perform a particular function in living organisms. Different organs of the human body, for instance, often are made from many different types of tissues.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: trait: A characteristic feature of something. (in genetics) A quality or characteristic that can be inherited.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a definition unrelated to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: transgenic: An organism that has had genetic material from an unrelated organism added to it.
annotations.reason: This provides relevant context about the genetic modification process used in the study.

annotations.paragraph: tundra: A cold, usually lowland area in far northern regions. The subsoil is permanently frozen. In summer, a tundra's top layer of soil thaws and can support low-growing mosses, lichens, grasses, shrubs and trees (some only a few centimeters high).
annotations.reason: This is unrelated background information not directly tied to the main premise.

annotations.paragraph: unique: Something that is unlike anything else; the only one of its kind.
annotations.reason: This is a general definition not directly related to the article's main topic.

annotations.paragraph: woolly mammoth: A type of extinct mammal that resembled a hairy elephant.
annotations.reason: This provides relevant context about the extinct animal that inspired the genetic research.
